Binding Properties

Binding is the process of setting a property of a view model inline. A propery of a view model can be bound to a static value, a constant or a property of the view model or any other view model defined earlier in the visual chain. The binding context is the same as a knockout binding context. For example <wo.contentControl model="{ innerModel: { value: 'The inner model' }, value: 'The model' }"> <template> <wo.contentControl model="$parent.model().innerModel" staticVal="'This is a static value'" constantVal="wo.DEBUG" bindToParent="$parent.model().value" bindToThis="model().value"> <template> <ul> <li> model().value: <span data-bind="text: model().value"></span> </li> <li> staticVal: <span data-bind="text: staticVal"></span> </li> <li> constantVal: <span data-bind="text: constantVal"></span> </li> <li> bindToParent: <span data-bind="text: bindToParent"></span> </li> <li> bindToThis: <span data-bind="text: bindToThis"></span> </li> </ul> </template> </wo.contentControl> </template> </wo.contentControl>

Binding to observables

In an MVVM pattern an update of a property should trigger updates to all properties bound to it. This is true in wipeout, as long as knockout observables are being used.

<wo.contentControl model="{ value: ko.observable('The model') }"> <template> Parent Text: <input type="text" data-bind="value: model().value, valueUpdate: 'keyup'" /> <wo.contentControl model="$parent.model().value"> <template> <div> Child Text: <input type="text" data-bind="value: model, valueUpdate: 'keyup'" /> </div> </template> </wo.contentControl> </template> </wo.contentControl>

Note that when the value property of the model is changed by the textbox, it triggers an update to the model property of the inner contentControl, however a change in the innerItemsControl does not signal the property it is bound to.

Two way bindings

By default bindings are one way, from the property referenced to the property set. In the following example

<wo.view viewProperty="model().modelProperty" />

A change to the model() or the property model().modelProperty will trigger a change in the viewProperty. However, a change in the view property will not trigger a change in the model().modelProperty. In order to force this behaviour, a two way binding can be used. This is basically the same syntax as a one way binding, with the "-tw" specifying the binding is multidirectional

<wo.view viewProperty-tw="model().modelProperty" />

For example:

<wo.contentControl model="{ value: ko.observable('The model') }"> <template> Parent Text: <input type="text" data-bind="value: model().value, valueUpdate: 'keyup'" /> <wo.contentControl model-tw="$parent.model().value"> <template> <div> Child Text: <input type="text" data-bind="value: model, valueUpdate: 'keyup'" /> </div> </template> </wo.contentControl> </template> </wo.contentControl>

Binding in code

View model properties can also be bound in . For example:

var myVm = new wo.view(); myVm.bind("model", theValueIWantToBindTo, false);
